citations.narrative:
Several sections of the perimeter fence sustained damage from a previous storm. Behind the giraffe enclosure was a
section of the perimeter fence, approximately 40 feet in length, that had portions of the upper crossbar bent or broken.
This caused the fence to dip down below 3 feet in height and several other portions did not meet the minimum height
requirement of 6 feet for NHPs, but 8 feet for some of the other species housed at the facility. There was also a gap
underneath this area of fence approximately 16 inches wide and 9 inches deep. This variation from the regulation was not
approved by the Administrator.
Animals and unauthorized people could use these damaged areas of the perimeter fence to gain access to the animals
behind it.
Fences less than 6 feet high must be approved by the Administrator and must be constructed so that it protects
nonhuman primates by restricting unauthorized humans, and animals the size of dogs, skunks, and raccoons from going
through it or under it. To be corrected before the next relicense inspection.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, there was no documented program of environmental enhancement for the non-human primates
housed at the facility.
An adequate environmental enhancement program is essential in promoting the psychological well-being of non-human
primates.
Dealers. Exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for environment
enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of non-human primates, it must be in accordance with
the currently accepted professional standards and as directed by the attending veterinarian. To be corrected by the next
relicense inspection.

The metal food receptacle, for two ring-tailed lemurs, was noted to have several areas of dusty, flaking rust.
Flaking rust can lead to contamination of the food and prevent proper cleaning and sanitation of the food receptacle.
Food receptacles must be kept clean and must be sanitized at least once every 2 weeks. To be corrected by the next
relicense inspection.

On the right side of the entrance to the covered portion of the camel enclosure, were three wooden poles. At
approximately 9 feet high, an exposed screw was observed protruding out of each of the poles, creating sharp points
facing outward toward the open area of the enclosure.
Failure to maintain enclosures in good repair can lead to animal injuries and escapes.
The indoor and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the
animals from injury and to contain the animals. The screws were removed at the time of inspection.

Several sections of the perimeter fence sustained damage from a previous storm. Behind the giraffe enclosure was a
section of the perimeter fence, approximately 40 feet in length, that had portions of the upper crossbar bent or broken.
This caused the fence to dip down below 3 feet in height and several other portions did not meet the minimum height
requirement of 8 feet. There was also a gap underneath this area of fence approximately 16 inches wide and 9 inches
deep.
Animals and unauthorized people could use these damaged areas of the perimeter fence to gain access to the animals
behind it.
The fence must be constructed so that it protects the animals in the facility by restricting animals and unauthorized
persons from going through it or under it and having contact with the animals in the facility, and so that it can function as a
secondary containment system for the animals in the facility. To be corrected before the next relicense inspection.

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
At the time of inspection, there was no documented program of environmental enhancement for the birds housed at the
facility.
An adequate environmental enhancement program is essential in promoting the psychological well-being of birds.
Dealers. Exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan for environment
enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds, it must be in accordance with the currently
accepted professional standards and as directed by the attending veterinarian. To be corrected by the next relicense
inspection.

Two metal food receptacles, one located in the blue and gold amazon cage, and the other located in the green winged
amazon cage, were noted to have several areas of dusty, flaking rust, and holes where the rust ate through the metal
containers.
Flaking rust can lead to contamination of the food and prevent proper cleaning and sanitation of the food receptacle.
Food receptacles must be made of a durable material that can be easily cleaned and sanitized or be replaced when worn
or soiled. To be corrected by the next relicense inspection.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by June 16, 2024, or the applicant will forfeit the license fee
and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
